pages.text: $(l:materials/Tungsten)Tungsten$(/l) $(l:materials/Steel)steel$(/l) is any $(l:materials/Steel)steel$(/l) that has $(l:materials/Tungsten)tungsten$(/l) as its alloying element with characteristics derived mostly from the presence of this element (as opposed to any other element in the alloy). Common alloys have between 2% and 18% $(l:materials/Tungsten)tungsten$(/l) by weight along with small amounts of $(l:materials/Molybdenum)molybdenum$(/l) and $(l:materials/Vanadium)vanadium$(/l) which together create an alloy with exceptional heat, corrosion, and wear resistance. $(l:materials/Tungsten)Tungsten$(/l) is one of the oldest elements

used for alloying $(l:materials/Steel)steel$(/l). It forms a very hard carbide and $(l:materials/Iron)iron$(/l) tungstite. High $(l:materials/Tungsten)tungsten$(/l) content in the alloy, however, tends to cause brittleness and makes it subject to fracturing rather than bending. The SAE designation for all $(l:materials/Tungsten)tungsten$(/l) steels consist of four numbers beginning with the number 7, in the format 7XXX.$(p)Tungsten $(l:materials/Steel)steel$(/l) is used for manufacturing micro-drill bits, high-durability self-
sharpening rotary cutting blades, and rocket engine nozzles, among many other applications.
